moves.1. d4 e6 2. e4 c5 3. Nf3 cxd4 4. Nxd4 a6: The Sicilan Narjof defence. I will leave the theory of this varation to others as I know very little about it.
moves.5. Nc3 Qc7 6. Qf3: I played this with the idea of Bf4 to follow
moves.6... Nf6 7. Bf4 e5 8. Bg3: Forced, but it has the advantage of putting preasure on e5
moves.8... Bb4: This is a very strong pin.
moves.9. Nf5:
Black can capture on c3 with a slightly better game for white. although after

9. ...Bxc3 10. Qxc3 Qxc3 11. bxc3 Nxe4 12.Nxg7 the position is unclear.
moves.9... O-O 10. O-O-O d6: Black should have played Bxc3 with equal chances.
moves.11. Nxg7: This is an excellent move I am sure vicpine did not see. The point is that the Knight is immune on account of 11. ...Kxg7 12. Qxf6  Kxf6 13. Nd5  with a monster fork!
moves.11... Qe7 12. Bh4: Black can not avoid the loss of material.
moves.12... Kxg7 13. Bxf6+ Qxf6 14. Qxf6+ Kxf6: This seals the centre and cramps blacks pieces.
moves.17... Nc6 18. Nb6 Rb8 19. Bc4 Be6 20. c3: Black can not take the bishop because he would have no way of defending d6 after the exchange.
moves.21. Bxe6 fxe6: This gives black some counter chances in the centre
moves.22. h4: so begins the pawn march on the king side. Black has nothing better to do than sit back and let white win.
moves.22... Kf6 23. Rh3: activating all the remaining forces into the game.
moves.23... Ke7 24. Rhd3: This ties black completely to the defense of d6. Allowing white to start a pawn march on the king side.
moves.24... Nc6 25. g4: grabs more space on the king side and further cramps blacks position.
moves.25... Na7: This knight is enroute to c8 where it can assist in the defense of d6
moves.26. Nc4 Nc8 27. g5 b5: This an attempt to create some counter play against the knight. However, this bad because it drops a pawn
moves.28. Nxe5: I grab another pawn exploiting the pin against the rook on e8
moves.28... Rb6: all of black's pieces are now tied to d6.
